summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons memorandum detailing an apparent suicide attempt by inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on July 23, 2019. The report includes conflicting accounts from Epstein and his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, about the incident, with Epstein later alleging Tartaglione attempted to kill him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who was found in his cell after an apparent suicide attempt. He later alleged his cellmate tried to kill him.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate who reported finding Epstein with a string around his neck and called for guards. Epstein later accused him of attempted murder.

connections.description: Were housed together in cell Z05-124LAD at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. Epstein accused Tartaglione of attempting to kill him.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: At approximately 1:27 a.m., Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell lying on the floor with a red neck, breathing heavily and snoring. A string was reportedly around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein's Legal Visit
events.description: Epstein returned from a legal visit at approximately 8:00 p.m. the evening before the incident.

events.title: Medical Examination
events.description: Epstein was later examined by medical staff and treated for a circular line of erythema at the base of his neck, with friction marks, and a small erythema on his left knee.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell on July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 a.m. with a red neck and reportedly a string around his neck, in an apparent suicide attempt.
Epstein later alleged to staff that his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, had attempted to kill him and had been harassing him, and claimed he had informed his attorney of this matter.
Tartaglione's account differed, stating he was asleep, felt something hit his legs, turned on the light, and saw Epstein with a string around his neck before calling the guards.

The report notes Epstein exhibited unpredictable behavior after the incident, including pretending to be unconscious when staff made eye contact and attempting to fall forward head-first while on suicide watch.
Medical assessment was delayed as no medical staff was available after 10:00 p.m.; when examined, Epstein had a circular line of erythema at the base of his neck with friction marks.
